title: Government plans to extend the 55pc pension tax trap
text:

Sat, Oct 17, 2015, 03:30 BST - UK Markets closed Government plans to extend the 55pc pension tax trap By Katie Morley | Telegraph – 16 hours ago 11.25 0.00 
Gold (Other OTC: GDCWF - news ) -plated 'final-salary' pensions could be subject to a lower lifetime limit, which would see savers pay more tax at 55pc 
Last week savers with the most generous types of work pension known as “final salary” or “defined benefit” were shocked to learn that the Government is gearing up for a major raid on their pensions. 
Telegraph Money disclosed Treasury plans to limit the tax reliefs, or Government top-ups, available to future contributions into such schemes. 
The blow would fall heavily on the upper ranks of the public sector, including MPs, civil servants, doctors and other NHS workers, and senior teachers, among others. 
Under the proposals, instead of being able to claim higher rate tax relief on pension contributions at a rate of 40pc, the relief will be limited to the basic 20pc rate. 
• Gov plans £7bn assault on final salary pension schemes 
But there could be another blow on the way for those with final salary pension entitlements. 
In private talks with the industry, ministers have also floated plans to reduce the lifetime pensions limit for this group of savers by as much as 25pc. This would mean more employees' pension pots would drift above the allowance, attracting the penal tax rate applying to the excess. This is as high as 55pc. 
= What is the lifetime limit? = 
This restricts the total value of the pension entitlements (excluding state pension) that any one person can build during their life. The limit currently stands at £1.25m and will fall to £1m in April (LSE: 0N69.L - news ) 2016. 
= What would a reduction in lifetime allowance mean for final salary pension savers? = 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) could mean savers lose £15,000 a year in retirement as the annual amount they could receive without exceeding the £1m limit might reduce from £50,000 to £35,000 a year. 
This is because final salary pension benefits are calculated differently for measuring against the limit. 
= Why the lifetime limit affects final salary savers differently = 
It’s easy for savers with defined contribution pensions to work out if they’ve exceeded the limit, because their retirement fund is essentially one big pot or lots of little ones. If the value of their pot(s) exceeds £1m, they know they will have to pay tax on the excess. 
For final salary savers it’s more complicated. This is because their pension value is expressed as a guaranteed retirement income, for example, £15,000 a year. 
To test the value against the lifetime limit, savers must times their predicted starting annual pension by 20. For example, a guaranteed income of £50,000 in retirement works out as a total fund value of £1m. 
This is around twice the annual income someone with a £1m defined contribution pension pot could expect to receive if they bought an annuity, which would provide a 65-year-old non-smoking male with around £26,000 a year. 
• Nine ways to improve your chances of retiring early • Get a weekly alert of pension advice and changes 
Because of this disparity, experts say the calculation is likely to be revised to make it less generous. If the standard measure moved to multiplying annual income by 29, instead of 20, savers would have final salary benefits capped at around £35,000 a year. 
According to Alan Higham, founder of pensionschamp.com, such a move would sting a graduate starting on a £27,000 salary today for £390,000 in tax penalties. 
He said: “On retirement at state pension age , given an estimated increase in wage over his career, his pension will be around £71,000 a year in today’s terms. Under current arrangements, because this would breach the £50,000 (£1m lifetime allowance), he would pay £5,250 in additional income tax per year, totalling about £130,000 over his retirement. 
“Under the proposed system, he would pay an additional £260,000 in income tax ‘penalties’ over the course of his retirement.” 
The total cost of overstepping his lifetime allowance would reach a staggering £390,000. 
While this seems harsh, many argue that such a move is necessary to level the playing field between more common defined contribution pensions and generous final salary schemes, increasingly limited to the public sector. 
A source close to the talks told Telegraph Money that higher taxation of final salary schemes is “low hanging fruit” for the Government. 
They added that a reduction in tax relief for these savers would be highly unlikely to stop them saving because the arrangements would remain “very generous”.
